Answer: Transfer learning in ML models.Humans are really good at generalizing. We only have to see a few dogs before we can recognize a dog when we see one.Machines are not. ML models require millions of examples before forming a reliable classifier, and that classifier is very specific to the data on which it was trained. If your training data doesn't include dogs with three legs, the model won't recognize them. A machine that plays Go is useless at checkers.Transfer learning is the ability to apply a model from one domain to a different one. It's hypothesized that the reason humans learn so quicklyTransfer learning in ML models.Humans are really good at generalizing. We only have to see a few dogs before we can recognize a dog when we see one.Machines are not. ML models require millions of examples before forming a reliable classifier, and that classifier is very specific to the data on which it was trained. If your training data doesn't include dogs with three legs, the model won't recognize them. A machine that plays Go is useless at checkers.Transfer learning is the ability to apply a model from one domain to a different one. It's hypothesized that the reason humans learn so quickly is that we are fitting new examples into our existing knowledge rather than forming entirely new categories. If we could teach machines to do the same, they would learn exponentially faster and apply that learning more effectively.Transfer learning is a very hot topic in AI research right now, so I expect major breakthroughs in the next few years. I think this may be sufficient to achieve artificial general intelligence, but even if not, it will dramatically extend the range of tasks that machines can accomplish.

Answer: I think the next big form of travel will be no travel.So much of what we do can now be done remotely. Four generations up, the most important thing one does was tending crops. That can not be done remotely. Two generations back, there was very little to be done remotely. One generation ago, you could pick up the phone, but that’s about it. Now, sitting in my chair I answer questions of somebody in the world on Quora. This is how I work too, sit in my chair and push buttons on my keyboard.In the future, people will be videoconferencing and such even more. Much of the work being done is being doI think the next big form of travel will be no travel.So much of what we do can now be done remotely. Four generations up, the most important thing one does was tending crops. That can not be done remotely. Two generations back, there was very little to be done remotely. One generation ago, you could pick up the phone, but that’s about it. Now, sitting in my chair I answer questions of somebody in the world on Quora. This is how I work too, sit in my chair and push buttons on my keyboard.In the future, people will be videoconferencing and such even more. Much of the work being done is being done by people sitting in front of screens and by automatons. In another two generations of time, I believe this trend will be even more pronounced.So my guess is in 50–100 years, the biggest form of travel will be the internet. After all, even today, you can using the internet wear your 3D goggles and visually visit almost anywhere on the Earth using photos and camera footage. Partly, you get sounds too. Smells and feelings might arrive soon if anybody will be interested in them. Virtual online meetings, virtual tourism. It costs way less time. And human individual time is worth more and more.

Answer: Interest in AI, work in AI has been around since about the 1950s. The most exciting idea and the goal of most of the earlier work has been General AI - AI that does pretty much what people do. A lot of the early decades of work actually tried to model how the human brain works - or, actually, trying to model various theories people had about how the brain worked. There was a lot of interesting thinking and work done in these areas by many people - including Marvin Minsky (a real nice guy, as well as a smart guy), Seymour Papert, and many others. But we didn’t really get much done with those idInterest in AI, work in AI has been around since about the 1950s. The most exciting idea and the goal of most of the earlier work has been General AI - AI that does pretty much what people do. A lot of the early decades of work actually tried to model how the human brain works - or, actually, trying to model various theories people had about how the brain worked. There was a lot of interesting thinking and work done in these areas by many people - including Marvin Minsky (a real nice guy, as well as a smart guy), Seymour Papert, and many others. But we didn’t really get much done with those ideas - probably ideas not practical and correct enough, not enough computing power.In the 1970s, ‘80s, ‘90s, rule-based AI - programs written by human domain experts to try and create specialized programs, and sometime fairly sophisticated high-end hardware, for particular problem domains, made some real progress. But for highly specialized, particular problems - like chess. But rule-based AI didn’t really make any progress toward the ultimately desirable General AI.Also around 1980, we started to see work being done in neural networks - webs of moderately simple and quite living-thing-like software “neurons” - software elements that can take multiple inputs, and when they get enough “activation” on their inputs, will “fire” - give an output. The seminal text, that assembled and organized key work up to that point and really introduced and popularized the technique of neural networks, was “PDP (Parallel Distributed Processing)” by David Rumelhart and James McClelland. (I was one of the editors.)A very key element in productive use of neural networks has been, rather than a human or even a program trying to give weights to the connections, the development of data-based training methods. The combination of training methods and greatly increased computational resources largely thru the availability of easily fabricated multiprocessor GPUs (based, in part, on my proposal of VLIW - Very Long Instruction Word processor architecture in 1979 and 1980), and in the past 10 or so years increased computational resources and vastly larger availability of training data sets have given much greater results. The development of Deep Learning - hierarchical ways to group and layer neural networks to address different abstraction layers of tasks, has also made a critical contribution.Modern AIs are not usually trying to be General AI’s. They are trying to produce useful, human-oriented results. There is little interest in the relationship between how they work and how a human works. We are appreciating and using the results we are getting. Those results are far more widely integrated into the daily conduct of your life than you realize. Think about how much you use your smartphone. Then think about how much you take it for granted. AI is already in about that situation in your life, but more hidden as a component of actions, not visible as a device you hold in your hand. Day by day, the presence and pervasiveness of AI increases. (This is different than the Pervasive Computing model that I proposed in the 1990s. Think of IoT as a week interpretation of that Pervasive.) In 5 or so years, modes of interaction, activities, and tasks that fundamentally incorporate AI will be as common and normal in your life as your smartphone is now.

Answer: It has existed in a primitive and limited form for some time: computers that play chess, for example, seem intelligent, but they are only increasingly elaborate algorithms running on faster machines.The next stage is machine learning, whereby an AI program can actually alter itself and interpret data more effectively, somewhat resembling the way humans learn through trial and error. There is already progress being made in this area.One of the main concerns about AI is that it could become good enough to replace humans in higher level cognitive tasks, such as interpreting legal documents and diIt has existed in a primitive and limited form for some time: computers that play chess, for example, seem intelligent, but they are only increasingly elaborate algorithms running on faster machines.The next stage is machine learning, whereby an AI program can actually alter itself and interpret data more effectively, somewhat resembling the way humans learn through trial and error. There is already progress being made in this area.One of the main concerns about AI is that it could become good enough to replace humans in higher level cognitive tasks, such as interpreting legal documents and diagnosing diseases. The obvious result of this is that it could lead to large numbers of highly trained people without work, which is clearly a serious problem.I am less concerned with the idea of a sufficiently powerful AI deciding to take over the world. Human volition, including the desire for power, is inextricable from being embodied entities with biological drives that have evolved over billions of years. We certainly don't come close to understanding the nature of our own consciousness, and even if someone was foolish enough to attempt to program human urges into an AI, they would almost certainly get it wrong: Even if they got it right, the basic motivational drives such as sex, hunger and survival, not to mention pride and the desire for status, would make no sense to a machine with no stomach or genitals.

Answer: AI is one of these fields that is so easy for the general public and popular culture to misinterpret and extrapolate way beyond reality. And you are correct, as a field it has been around for ever and I am old enough to remember a time that failure to deliver on the grand promises made working in AI almost an embarrassment. But people forget and everything comes around again, so now AI is the big thing again, probably because of our ability to utilize pattern matching at such larger scale than before which leads to pretty reasonable software/systems that can at least come somewhere near a humaAI is one of these fields that is so easy for the general public and popular culture to misinterpret and extrapolate way beyond reality. And you are correct, as a field it has been around for ever and I am old enough to remember a time that failure to deliver on the grand promises made working in AI almost an embarrassment. But people forget and everything comes around again, so now AI is the big thing again, probably because of our ability to utilize pattern matching at such larger scale than before which leads to pretty reasonable software/systems that can at least come somewhere near a human’s ability to perceive and recognize situations. But we are still far away from creating this:But your question is interesting, why does AI get so much press, so to speak. I think part of it is because as a topic, it is easy enough for most people to understand. At the same time, without hands-on or deeper knowledge of the tools and techniques it is so easy for a lay person to get out of control in dreaming of what someday could be possible. Try at a cocktail party to talk to someone about sensor fusion and how Kalman filtering facilitated us getting to the moon and you will find yourself alone pretty quickly. On the other hand, throw some words such as artificial intelligence, data mining, deep learning, virtual reality and everyone becomes a futurist, predicting how before we know it computers will become human-smart, will do our thinking for us and how we are almost there because they saw a robot that gave instructions to people at an airport.It also doesn’t help that the plot of just about any sci-fi movie depends either entirely or at least partially on some version of machines becoming smart and taking over the house, city or world. Alternatively, if the machines don’t take over, somehow an intelligent android or other service robot that is smarter than most people alive today, just happens to be a normal possession in every home (or was developed by a single genius scientist in their workshop). To say nothing of the tired old “I have no emotion until my creator added an ‘emotion chip’ and now I’m angry”.Over 30 years ago, AI was the big thing - computers would be able to reason and become so smart they would think for us. In reality, we got a paper-clip that nobody could use and lately Siri. So as usual, what people pass as disruptive technology is nothing more than evolutionary and gradual improvements to old technology.

Answer: It is both very close and far away, depending on which AI takes the lead, real or fake.Today's Pseudo-AI, led by the Big Tech ML/DL big data analytics platforms, is the snake oil of the 21st century.In the 19th century, salesmen would travel around selling ‘snake oil’ as a panacea. But most of these elixirs and ointments held no medicinal benefits, and did not contain oil extracted from snakes. So rampant was this con, that snake oil became a universal term for fake products and false promises.Fast forward to the 21st century. Snake oil products have evolved over the ages, slithering their wayIt is both very close and far away, depending on which AI takes the lead, real or fake.Today's Pseudo-AI, led by the Big Tech ML/DL big data analytics platforms, is the snake oil of the 21st century.In the 19th century, salesmen would travel around selling ‘snake oil’ as a panacea. But most of these elixirs and ointments held no medicinal benefits, and did not contain oil extracted from snakes. So rampant was this con, that snake oil became a universal term for fake products and false promises.Fast forward to the 21st century. Snake oil products have evolved over the ages, slithering their way into modern technology.The tech industry today is full of software snake oil. It takes many forms, from vapourware and futureware to over-egged promises of functionality. But the crown jewel of tech snake oil? Apparently, it’s AI.Hype and ignoranceSo, why are so many companies selling AI snake oil?The first reason is that they are cashing in on the hype. Start-ups with an ‘AI’ classification attract as much as 15 – 50% more funding. Investors are eager to catch the AI train early, as the term grows more and more into a buzzword.Another reason may simply be due to consumer assumption. Many of the AI snake oil companies in the survey aren’t classifying themselves as AI – others are. They aren’t explicitly promising AI, people are adding that label themselves. The companies may even be ignorant of this classification. In this sense, they aren’t selling AI snake oil, but their customers are buying it.And finally, there’s a miscommunication or misunderstanding of what AI is. Artificial intelligence is so overused as a label that it’s losing its meaning. As a result, non-AI applications are inadvertently presented as AI. This flavour of AI snake oil most often occurs with automation software, as rule-based systems like business process automation are pushed as AI.Real AI is on the upArtificial intelligence has become a buzzword. It’s the snake oil of the tech industry in the 21st century.But for all the AI snake oil out there, real artificial intelligence is on the up. It’s not all lies, misdirection and vapourware. So, if something is claiming to be AI, it may well be. We just need to be a little bit more sceptical for the time being.AI: the snake oil of the 21st century - ThinkAutomationBusiness process automation is not AI; it’s a rule-based system that uses conditional processingPredictive analytics is not AIMachine learning is not AI; automating regression tasks to draw n-dimensional lines though data pointsDeep learning is not AIREAL Artificial Intelligence does not need masses of training data to work.ML is a buzzword in technology; it is NOT a branch of REAL artificial intelligence that lets machines learn new skills and solve new problems.Without real understanding/intelligence/intellect, machine learning UNABLE "to teach machines how to solve problems, answer questions and draw conclusions from source material without human intervention" or "teach computers to act like the human brain by learning autonomously over time".Without real understanding/intelligence/intellect, machine learning can NOT enable computers to learn how to detect potential cases of fraud across many different fields, such as in finance and banking; how to identify the sentiment behind the messages a customer sends; how best to reply to customer queries; how to provide earlier, more accurate medical diagnosis, etc.

Answer: We are all familiar with inkjet printers that spray different coloured inks across a surface to produce fantastically detailed colour pictures. We are also familiar with 8K HDTV where millions of tiny LED are flashed on an off to produce fantastically crisp colour images and video.Now imagine technology built on the same scale that spray different propellant across an aWe are all familiar with inkjet printers that spray different coloured inks across a surface to produce fantastically detailed colour pictures. We are also familiar with 8K HDTV where millions of tiny LED are flashed on an off to produce fantastically crisp colour images and video.Now imagine technology built on the same scale that spray different propellant across an array of nozzles that produce fantastically detailed patterns of forces across a surface that weighs every little yet controlled in very much the same ay as an HDTV screen.Micro Electro Mechanical Systems (MEMS) based rocket engines that create propulsive skins with 1000 to 1 thrust to weight. Improved thrust to weight derives from the fact that propulsive force from a rocket scales with the area of the rocket whilst the weight of a rocket scales with the volume. So, by reducing the size of a rocket thrust goes up faster than weight. Further, explosive energy scales with the volume as well whilst strength scales with area. So, by reducing the size of a rocket, reliablity goes up for a given weight as well.These propulsive skins have far fewer failure modes and are easily flown 100,000 times before being replaced. Further, they do not fail even after tens of millions of firings. This makes them competitive with jet airplanes in terms of reusability and reliabilty and safety.So we end up with surfaces similar to HDTV screens where there are millions of very tiny rocket engines each of which is highly reliable, but in the event of a single engine failing the bulk of the surface continues to operate. Just as an HDTV screen creates moving colour images, the propulsive skin array creates moving vectors across the surface to provide precise and reliable control.http://cap.ee.ic.ac.uk/~pdm97/powermems/2005/pdfs/153_Epstein.pdfhttps://mtlsites.mit.edu/annual_reports/2002/mems/rocket_engines.pdfAn array of 1/10th inch diameter nozzle operating at 150x atmospheric pressure in tiny combustion chambers each with a 1/100th inch diameter throat produces 2.2 pounds of force (9.81 Newtons (1 kgf)) of thrust with 5.176 grains/second (335.4 milligrams/sec) of hydrogen and 28.470 grains/second (1844.6 milligrams/sec) of oxygen.A square inch of this propulsive array produces 265 pounds of thrust (1135 Newtons (115 kgf)) and weighs around 4 ounces (114 grams).A liquid hydrogen/liquid oxygen rocket maintains a 10,100 mph (16,200 kph (4.5 km/sec)) exhaust speed at sea level and produces 265 pounds per square inch (1.62 MN/m2) of propulsive area.Just as each dot in a HDTV screen has one of three primary colours each thrust element in the propulsive skin has three primary directions and a resultant engine whose thrust can vary between 0.1 pounds to 2.5 pounds with 2.2 pounds being nominal. Three of the engines are at right angles to one another. The fourth is pointed along the diagonal of the box edges made by the other three. The diagonal is pointed normal to the surface. By varying the thrust in each thrust element the resultant thrust at that point is made to vary over a range of directions described by a cone with a 45 degree opening angle from each point, giving a high degree of control across the surface without gimbals, vanes or other moving surfaces.A propulsive skin consisting of millions of tiny rocket engines as described form a band around the edge of an aerospike nozzle. Such nozzles work well at all altitudes.An aerospike nozzle attached to the base of a 29.5 foot (9 meter) diameter ship is shaped very much like a Space Shuttle external tank only slightly larger. That is 173.9 ft (53 meters) long and carries 1,925,000 pounds (873 tonnes) of propellant — 296,153.9 pounds LH2 and 1,628,846.1 pounds LOX — the ship itself weighs 70,850 pounds. The aerospike shaped tail section has a ring of propulsive skin. The band is wide enough to propel the entire system at lift off with a thrust of 1.8 gee. (17.65 m/s2, 57.91 ft/s2)The ship is capable of attaining a speed of 16,800 mph (27,000 kph, 7.5 km/sec).1925000/(1–1/exp(16800/10100))=2,375,077 pounds total weight1.8*2375077/1000 = 4,275 pounds engine weight1925000/(1–1/exp(16800/10100))-1925000 - 70850 - 4275 = 374,952 poundsPayload is 374,952 pounds (170.1 metric tons)The 375,152 pound useful load is contained in a cylindrical extension located between a liquid oxygen tank in the nose of the ship and the hydrogen tank in the tail. This extension 29.5 feet (9 meters) in diameter and 173.9 feet (52 meters) long. It weighs 70,850 pounds and leaves 304,152 pounds of usefu...

We might use ion drives or eInterplanetary - Matter / AntimatterInterstellar - Matter / AntimatterIntergalactic - Matter / AntimatterAt the end of the day, antimatter has the highest possible energy density of any fuel - 100% of it is converted to energy. We are already close to being able to make antimatter, and we’ll solve the manufacture / storage problem.There are details to be resolved (focusing the emitted radiation not least among them) but they don’t appear unsolvable.Once solved, antimatter engines could propel ships very near to the speed of light, and with a minimum amount of fuel. We might use ion drives or even rockets (gasp) for very short trips, but for most of our flights, it’s antimatter or bust.

Answer: Regrettably, probably nothing.All forms of motion are action/reaction. There can be no reactionless drive without violating those pesky laws of physics. The only way to move forward in space is to throw something out the back. So it seems that the rocket, in some form, is the only effective way to go.The ion rocket gives a lot of efficiency for the fuel mass but it’s babies breath thrust makes it totally unsuitable for manned trips. Still, it makes long duration robotic missions more feasible.Humans are not suitable for long duration missions, so it is necessary to use chemical rockets for higRegrettably, probably nothing.All forms of motion are action/reaction. There can be no reactionless drive without violating those pesky laws of physics. The only way to move forward in space is to throw something out the back. So it seems that the rocket, in some form, is the only effective way to go.The ion rocket gives a lot of efficiency for the fuel mass but it’s babies breath thrust makes it totally unsuitable for manned trips. Still, it makes long duration robotic missions more feasible.Humans are not suitable for long duration missions, so it is necessary to use chemical rockets for high impulse thrust but efficiency is low.Using fission nuclear power is somewhat more efficient but is pretty much a non starter due to necessary heavy shielding and inherent dangers of launching large quantities of fission fuel.Not to be confused with Plutonium RTG’s, using small quantities of P-238, that provide low levels of electrical power for long terms where Solar power is useless.Fusion fuel is a big question mark as at this point as we can’t even make controlled nuclear fusion on the ground where there is no concern of launch weight or safety. It’s not really clear how fusion power would translate to controllable thrust. Maybe that will work out in time…maybe not.I hope we can have controlled nuclear fusion in the future, at least for electrical generation on the ground but it has proved elusive and always 20–30 years away. Solar and wind won’t cut it as the sole grid power source.So there you have it. Remember that Star Trek is fantasy based on impossible technology. There will be no “impulse” or “warp” drives. Not until someone invents the magic wand.

Answer: I’d bet on the use of nuclear-powered or even solar-powered ion propulsion for manned space missions out beyond the Moon and for orbit maintenance on the ISS or its replacement.. Ion propulsion itself has already proven itself on deep space (out to the asteroid belt) unmanned probes. Even the quite low thrust of an array of nuclear-powered Hall thrusters could radically shorten a manned mission to Mars and make the moons of the outer planets do-able!Note that a very small set of Hall thrusters would be required for ISS “station keeping”, so it’s almost a “No Brainer” even if the nuclear phobiaI’d bet on the use of nuclear-powered or even solar-powered ion propulsion for manned space missions out beyond the Moon and for orbit maintenance on the ISS or its replacement.. Ion propulsion itself has already proven itself on deep space (out to the asteroid belt) unmanned probes. Even the quite low thrust of an array of nuclear-powered Hall thrusters could radically shorten a manned mission to Mars and make the moons of the outer planets do-able!Note that a very small set of Hall thrusters would be required for ISS “station keeping”, so it’s almost a “No Brainer” even if the nuclear phobia demanded solar power!I could easily imagine a Spacex Starship being mated to a “Superheavy” booster in orbit where the SuperHeavy has some number of its 30 chemical engines replaced with arrays of Hall thrusters and some of its fuel capacity replaced with a full blown 50MW (or smaller) fission reactor! (Let’s look closely at the “SuperHeavy” when it rolls out! Could it be stacked to allow one conventional SuperHeavy to orbit a second SuperHeavy possibly without its onboard fuel and oxydizer but with a nuclear reactor, electrical power production system, and cooling fins!). It’s using today’s technology but it would get the job done!
